abstract: Returns the relationship for the given relationship of the object with a given object ID.

declaration.code: func newValue(forRelationship relationship: NSRelationshipDescription, forObjectWith objectID: NSManagedObjectID, with context: NSManagedObjectContext?) throws -> Any

overview:
## Return Value

The value of the relationship specified `relationship` of the object with object ID `objectID`, or `nil` if an error occurs.

## Discussion

If the relationship is a to-one, the method should return an [doc://com.apple.coredata/documentation/CoreData/NSManagedObjectID] instance that identifies the destination, or an instance of [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSNull] if the relationship value is `nil`.

If the relationship is a to-many, the method should return a collection object containing [doc://com.apple.coredata/documentation/CoreData/NSManagedObjectID] instances to identify the related objects. Using an `NSArray` instance is preferred because it will be the most efficient. A store may also return an instance of `NSSet` or `NSOrderedSet`; an instance of `NSDictionary` is not acceptable.

If an object with object ID `objectID` cannot be found, the method should return `nil` and—if `error` is not `NULL`—create and return an appropriate error object in `error`.

# newValue(forRelationship:forObjectWith:with:)

**Instance Method**

Returns the relationship for the given relationship of the object with a given object ID.

## Declaration

```swift
func newValue(forRelationship relationship: NSRelationshipDescription, forObjectWith objectID: NSManagedObjectID, with context: NSManagedObjectContext?) throws -> Any
```

## Parameters

- **relationship**: The relationship for which values are requested.
- **objectID**: The ID of the object for which values are requested.
- **context**: The managed object context into which values will be returned.

## Return Value

The value of the relationship specified `relationship` of the object with object ID `objectID`, or `nil` if an error occurs.

## Discussion

If the relationship is a to-one, the method should return an [doc://com.apple.coredata/documentation/CoreData/NSManagedObjectID] instance that identifies the destination, or an instance of [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSNull] if the relationship value is `nil`.

If the relationship is a to-many, the method should return a collection object containing [doc://com.apple.coredata/documentation/CoreData/NSManagedObjectID] instances to identify the related objects. Using an `NSArray` instance is preferred because it will be the most efficient. A store may also return an instance of `NSSet` or `NSOrderedSet`; an instance of `NSDictionary` is not acceptable.

If an object with object ID `objectID` cannot be found, the method should return `nil` and—if `error` is not `NULL`—create and return an appropriate error object in `error`.

## Manipulating Managed Objects

- **execute(_:with:)**: Returns a value as appropriate for the given request, or nil if the request cannot be completed.
- **newValuesForObject(with:with:)**: Returns an incremental store node encapsulating the persistent external values of the object with a given object ID.
- **obtainPermanentIDs(for:)**: Returns an array containing the object IDs for a given array of newly-inserted objects.
- **newObjectID(for:referenceObject:)**: Returns a new object ID that uses given data as the key.
- **referenceObject(for:)**: Returns the reference data used to construct a given object ID.
